content.thinking:
The error is a classic KServe webhook timing issue. The KServe controller pod (which serves the webhook) isn't ready yet when Helm tries to install the main chart, so the webhook validation calls fail with "connection refused".

Let me look at the setup_kserve_knative.sh script to understand the current flow and figure out how to fix it.

file.content:
#!/usr/bin/env bash
# KServe Knative mode installation.
# Follows the KServe Knative serverless deployment guide:
#   https://kserve.github.io/website/latest/admin/serverless/serverless/
#
# Versions (Kubernetes 1.32 recommended matrix):
#   Knative      v1.19.0
#   Istio        1.28.0
#   Cert Manager v1.15.0
#   KServe       v0.16.0
#
# Prerequisite: a running Kubernetes 1.32+ cluster with kubectl configured.
# KServe is installed via Helm when available, falling back to YAML.
set -e

KNATIVE_VERSION="v1.19.0"
ISTIO_VERSION="1.28.0"
CERT_MANAGER_VERSION="v1.15.0"
KSERVE_VERSION="v0.16.0"

# ── 1. Install Knative Serving ────────────────────────────────────────────────
echo "knative: installing Serving CRDs …"
kubectl apply -f "https://github.com/knative/serving/releases/download/knative-${KNATIVE_VERSION}/serving-crds.yaml"

echo "knative: installing Serving core …"
kubectl apply -f "https://github.com/knative/serving/releases/download/knative-${KNATIVE_VERSION}/serving-core.yaml"

echo "knative: waiting for Serving to be ready …"
kubectl wait --for=condition=Available deployment --all -n knative-serving --timeout=300s

# ── 2. Install Networking Layer (Istio + net-istio) ───────────────────────────
echo "istio  : downloading istioctl ${ISTIO_VERSION} …"
curl -sSL https://istio.io/downloadIstio | ISTIO_VERSION="${ISTIO_VERSION}" TARGET_ARCH="$(uname -m)" sh -
export PATH="${PWD}/istio-${ISTIO_VERSION}/bin:${PATH}"

echo "istio  : installing …"
istioctl install -y

echo "istio  : waiting for ingress gateway …"
kubectl wait --for=condition=Available deployment --all -n istio-system --timeout=300s

echo "istio  : installing Knative net-istio …"
kubectl apply -f "https://github.com/knative/net-istio/releases/download/knative-${KNATIVE_VERSION}/net-istio.yaml"

# ── 3. Install Cert Manager ───────────────────────────────────────────────────
echo "certmgr: installing Cert Manager ${CERT_MANAGER_VERSION} …"
kubectl apply -f "https://github.com/cert-manager/cert-manager/releases/download/${CERT_MANAGER_VERSION}/cert-manager.yaml"

echo "certmgr: waiting for Cert Manager to be ready …"
kubectl wait --for=condition=Available deployment --all -n cert-manager --timeout=300s

# ── 4. Install KServe ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
if command -v helm &>/dev/null; then
  echo "kserve : installing CRDs via Helm …"
  helm install kserve-crd oci://ghcr.io/kserve/charts/kserve-crd --version "${KSERVE_VERSION}"

  echo "kserve : installing controller via Helm …"
  helm install kserve oci://ghcr.io/kserve/charts/kserve --version "${KSERVE_VERSION}"
else
  echo "kserve : helm not found — installing via YAML …"
  kubectl apply --server-side \
    -f "https://github.com/kserve/kserve/releases/download/${KSERVE_VERSION}/kserve.yaml"

  echo "kserve : installing built-in ClusterServingRuntimes …"
  kubectl apply --server-side \
    -f "https://github.com/kserve/kserve/releases/download/${KSERVE_VERSION}/kserve-cluster-resources.yaml"
fi

echo "kserve : Knative mode installation complete"

content.thinking:
The issue is clear: the KServe CRDs are installed first (which also installs the webhook server), but then when trying to install the main KServe chart, the webhook server pod isn't ready yet. The webhook validates `ClusterServingRuntime` resources, but the KServe controller/webhook isn't running yet.

The fix is to add a `kubectl wait` after installing the CRDs (and before installing the controller chart), waiting for the KServe webhook server to be ready. Actually wait - looking at this more carefully:

1. `helm install kserve-crd` - installs CRDs only (no webhook pod)


2. `helm install kserve` - installs the controller chart, which creates the webhook server pod and also tries to create ClusterServingRuntimes as part of the chart, triggering webhook validation before the server is ready

This is a chicken-and-egg problem since the webhook is part of the same chart being installed. The solution would be to either split the chart installation into stages with a wait in between, or use Helm hooks to delay the ClusterServingRuntime creation until the webhook is ready. The real solution is to use the `--wait` flag with helm install so it actually waits for the webhook pod to be ready before considering the installation complete, rather than just registering the webhook and immediately trying to create resources that need it. The issue is that during the same Helm install, the webhook configuration gets created before the webhook pod is actually ready to handle requests, so when Helm tries to apply the ClusterServingRuntimes, the validation fails because the webhook endpoint isn't responding yet.

The practical solution is to install the CRDs first, wait for the kserve controller and its webhook to be fully ready, then proceed with installing the actual chart—but I'm realizing the webhook doesn't even exist until after the initial install completes, so this creates a chicken-and-egg problem that needs more thought. The real issue is that the Helm chart bundles the ClusterServingRuntimes with the controller, so the webhook validation fires before the controller pod is actually ready to handle them. I need to either disable those resources in the chart values, use a retry mechanism, or split the installation into separate phases where I install the CRDs first, wait for the controller to be ready, then apply the runtime resources afterward. I'm exploring whether the KServe Helm chart has a configuration option to disable ClusterServingRuntimes installation, which would let me install the chart successfully and then apply those resources separately once the webhook is ready. I'm considering a third approach where I install the CRD separately first, then retry the controller installation in a loop to handle timing issues with the webhook becoming available.

But actually, looking at the root cause more carefully—the webhook error suggests the ValidatingWebhookConfiguration is already registered from a previous installation, pointing to a service that either doesn't exist yet or whose pod hasn't started. The Helm chart likely creates the webhook configuration as a Kubernetes resource, then immediately tries to apply ClusterServingRuntimes, which triggers the webhook before it's actually ready to handle requests.

The better approach for local development is to split the installation: first install just the CRDs, then install the controller and webhook, wait for them to be ready, and finally apply the serving runtimes. I should check if the KServe Helm chart has a flag to skip the serving runtime resources during installation so I can apply them separately after the webhook is fully operational. The most straightforward solution is to add the `--wait` flag to the helm install command and then apply the ClusterServingRuntimes as a separate step afterward. Looking at the Helm chart for kserve, if we use:
```bash
helm install kserve oci://ghcr.io/kserve/charts/kserve --version "${KSERVE_VERSION}" --wait --timeout 5m
```

The `--wait` flag tells Helm to wait until all Pods, PVCs, Services, and minimum number of Pods of a Deployment are in a ready state. This means the kserve-controller-manager pod should be ready before Helm reports success. But the issue is that Helm itself creates the webhook configuration and then tries to create ClusterServingRuntimes in the same transaction.

Actually, let me reconsider this practically—the `--wait` flag makes Helm wait for deployments to be ready before marking the release successful, but the problem happens during the install when Helm submits the ClusterServingRuntime resources. I need to think through the actual sequence: the kserve-crd chart should only install CRDs without the webhook, then the kserve controller chart installs the webhook and controller. The issue is timing—the webhook needs to be ready before any custom resources are created. The YAML approach with explicit wait steps is already available as a fallback in the script, so the real solution is to switch away from the Helm installation and use that instead, or modify the Helm approach to handle the webhook readiness issue before applying cluster resources.

Building the hybrid approach...

I'm reconsidering the strategy here—the hybrid method might leave Helm in a broken state on retries, which isn't ideal. Looking at the official KServe documentation for v0.16.0, the installation process is straightforward: install the CRD chart first, then the main chart. The webhook timing issue between registration and ClusterServingRuntimes creation is a known problem in the community, and the standard recommendation is to use extended timeouts with `--wait`, though that alone doesn't fully resolve it.

I'm weighing several options: using Helm with longer timeouts, temporarily adjusting the webhook failure policy (not great practice), skipping Helm entirely for the CRD chart, or installing Helm with ClusterServingRuntimes disabled and applying them afterward. For a local development setup, the cleanest and most reliable approach is to stick with the pure YAML installation method, which naturally sequences everything correctly—CRDs first, then the controller, then cluster resources.

Applying KServe resources via YAML with server-side apply... I'm considering a fallback approach where if the initial Helm install fails due to webhook timing issues, I'll wait for the controller to be ready and then retry the installation, uninstalling the failed attempt first.

Looking at the KServe Helm chart, I'm wondering if there's a way to disable the ClusterServingRuntimes creation through chart values to avoid the webhook timing problem altogether, but I'd need to verify the exact configuration options available in the chart.

This gives the webhook time to initialize properly before it needs to validate anything. **The simplest and most idiomatic fix**: Add a pre-install wait in the kserve chart by waiting for the cert-manager certificate to be issued and the webhook to be configured. Actually this doesn't help.

2. Install kserve chart WITHOUT ClusterServingRuntimes (

A better strategy would be to check if the failure is specifically webhook-related and only proceed if it is, otherwise exit with the actual error. But the cleanest solution is to always run the helm install, wait for the controller to be ready regardless of the install outcome, then apply the ClusterServingRuntimes afterward.

Writing the helm installation script... The retry logic works because the first install attempt creates the deployment even though Helm reports failure due to webhook timing issues, then waiting for the controller to be ready and reinstalling should succeed since the image is cached. Though there's a potential risk: if the second install hits the same timing problem, the cached image might help it complete faster, but it's not guaranteed.

A more reliable approach would be a two-phase install using Helm values to skip the ClusterServingRuntimes on the first pass, then enable them once the controller is ready. Since I can't verify the exact chart values right now, I'll use a YAML-based installation method instead, which gives me explicit control over the ordering and lets me install the CRDs first, then the controller separately.

Writing the Helm install commands... I've been going in circles trying to fix the webhook timing issue with the helm install. Let me step back and commit to a straightforward approach: I'll modify the helm command to handle failures gracefully, then apply the cluster resources separately after ensuring the webhook is ready, which should make the process idempotent regardless of whether helm or YAML installation is used.

Looking at the actual helm install command, I notice it's installing into the default namespace where the webhook service also lives. I'm realizing that `helm install --wait` would make Helm wait for resources to be ready, but the real issue is that Helm applies resources sequentially—the webhook gets registered and then the ClusterServingRuntimes are created in the same operation, which causes the timing conflict.

Let me think through this more carefully: `--wait` actually waits for all resources to reach ready state at the end of the install, not between each resource. So it wouldn't solve the ordering problem where the webhook is trying to validate resources that don't exist yet. The real fix would be ensuring the webhook deployment is fully ready before any custom resources that need validation are created.

I'll go with a practical approach: install the CRDs and controller via Helm, then handle the webhook timing issue by catching the initial failure, waiting for the controller to be ready, and retrying the cluster resource creation. I'm writing a bash script that installs the Helm charts and includes error handling for this specific scenario.

Writing the installation script... I'm realizing there's a potential issue here—if the Helm install fails partway through, the kserve-controller-manager deployment might not exist yet, which would cause the kubectl wait command to timeout. And on subsequent script runs, Helm would fail because the release already exists in a failed state, so I'd need to use helm upgrade instead of helm install to handle that scenario.

Using `helm upgrade --install` solves the reinvocation problem since it'll upgrade an existing release rather than fail, but the core problem persists: if Helm fails and I suppress the error, the release stays in a failed state while some resources like the deployment and webhook config might already be partially created in the cluster.

The real solution is to handle this gracefully without breaking the script on non-webhook failures. I'm thinking I should log the Helm output to inspect what went wrong, then check if it's specifically a webhook timeout issue before deciding whether to continue or fail.

Checking for webhook-specific errors... I see now—KServe provides separate YAML files for this exact scenario: `kserve.yaml` contains the controller and webhooks without the ClusterServingRuntimes, while `kserve-cluster-resources.yaml` has just the CSRs. For a local dev setup though, the tradeoff is acceptable since the `kubectl wait` will catch actual problems and timeout with a clear error message. The real issue I need to address is idempotency: running the script twice will fail on the second `helm install` because the release already exists, so I should switch both kserve-crd and kserve to use `helm upgrade --install` instead.

The cleaner approach is to move the webhook wait and CSR application outside the if/else block so they run after either the Helm or YAML installation path completes. I'm also verifying that `helm upgrade --install` properly handles failed releases in Helm 3, which it does—so retrying on subsequent runs won't cause issues. Writing the Helm installation script... I'm verifying the namespace where the controller runs—the webhook service is in the default namespace, so that's where I need to wait for the deployment to be ready before applying the cluster resources.

content.text:
This is a classic KServe webhook timing race: the `kserve` Helm chart registers a `ValidatingWebhookConfiguration` and creates `ClusterServingRuntimes` in the same pass. The webhook pod isn't ready when the CSRs are submitted, so validation calls hit a "connection refused".

The fix: allow the helm install to fail on CSRs, wait for the controller to be ready, then apply cluster resources separately (idempotent).

input.old_string:
# ── 4. Install KServe ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
if command -v helm &>/dev/null; then
  echo "kserve : installing CRDs via Helm …"
  helm install kserve-crd oci://ghcr.io/kserve/charts/kserve-crd --version "${KSERVE_VERSION}"

  echo "kserve : installing controller via Helm …"
  helm install kserve oci://ghcr.io/kserve/charts/kserve --version "${KSERVE_VERSION}"
else
  echo "kserve : helm not found — installing via YAML …"
  kubectl apply --server-side \
    -f "https://github.com/kserve/kserve/releases/download/${KSERVE_VERSION}/kserve.yaml"

  echo "kserve : installing built-in ClusterServingRuntimes …"
  kubectl apply --server-side \
    -f "https://github.com/kserve/kserve/releases/download/${KSERVE_VERSION}/kserve-cluster-resources.yaml"
fi
input.new_string:
# ── 4. Install KServe ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
if command -v helm &>/dev/null; then
  echo "kserve : installing CRDs via Helm …"
  helm upgrade --install kserve-crd oci://ghcr.io/kserve/charts/kserve-crd \
    --version "${KSERVE_VERSION}"

  echo "kserve : installing controller via Helm …"
  # The chart registers a ValidatingWebhookConfiguration and ClusterServingRuntimes
  # in a single pass; the webhook pod may not be ready when CSRs are submitted,
  # producing a "connection refused" error.  Allow that failure — the controller
  # deployment is still created — and apply cluster resources once it is ready.
  helm upgrade --install kserve oci://ghcr.io/kserve/charts/kserve \
    --version "${KSERVE_VERSION}" --timeout 10m || true
else
  echo "kserve : helm not found — installing via YAML …"
  kubectl apply --server-side \
    -f "https://github.com/kserve/kserve/releases/download/${KSERVE_VERSION}/kserve.yaml"
fi

echo "kserve : waiting for controller manager to be ready …"
kubectl wait --for=condition=Available deployment/kserve-controller-manager \
  -n default --timeout=300s

echo "kserve : applying ClusterServingRuntimes …"
kubectl apply --server-side \
  -f "https://github.com/kserve/kserve/releases/download/${KSERVE_VERSION}/kserve-cluster-resources.yaml"

toolUseResult.oldString:
# ── 4. Install KServe ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
if command -v helm &>/dev/null; then
  echo "kserve : installing CRDs via Helm …"
  helm install kserve-crd oci://ghcr.io/kserve/charts/kserve-crd --version "${KSERVE_VERSION}"

  echo "kserve : installing controller via Helm …"
  helm install kserve oci://ghcr.io/kserve/charts/kserve --version "${KSERVE_VERSION}"
else
  echo "kserve : helm not found — installing via YAML …"
  kubectl apply --server-side \
    -f "https://github.com/kserve/kserve/releases/download/${KSERVE_VERSION}/kserve.yaml"

  echo "kserve : installing built-in ClusterServingRuntimes …"

toolUseResult.newString:
# ── 4. Install KServe ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
if command -v helm &>/dev/null; then
  echo "kserve : installing CRDs via Helm …"
  helm upgrade --install kserve-crd oci://ghcr.io/kserve/charts/kserve-crd \
    --version "${KSERVE_VERSION}"

  echo "kserve : installing controller via Helm …"
  # The chart registers a ValidatingWebhookConfiguration and ClusterServingRuntimes
  # in a single pass; the webhook pod may not be ready when CSRs are submitted,
  # producing a "connection refused" error.  Allow that failure — the controller
  # deployment is still created — and apply cluster resources once it is ready.
  helm upgrade --install kserve oci://ghcr.io/kserve/charts/kserve \
    --version "${KSERVE_VERSION}" --timeout 10m || true
else
  echo "kserve : helm not found — installing via YAML …"
  kubectl apply --server-side \
    -f "https://github.com/kserve/kserve/releases/download/${KSERVE_VERSION}/kserve.yaml"
fi

echo "kserve : waiting for controller manager to be ready …"
kubectl wait --for=condition=Available deployment/kserve-controller-manager \
  -n default --timeout=300s

echo "kserve : applying ClusterServingRuntimes …"
kubectl apply --server-side \
  -f "https://github.com/kserve/kserve/releases/download/${KSERVE_VERSION}/kserve-cluster-resources.yaml"
toolUseResult.originalFile:
#!/usr/bin/env bash
# KServe Knative mode installation.
# Follows the KServe Knative serverless deployment guide:
#   https://kserve.github.io/website/latest/admin/serverless/serverless/
#
# Versions (Kubernetes 1.32 recommended matrix):
#   Knative      v1.19.0
#   Istio        1.28.0
#   Cert Manager v1.15.0
#   KServe       v0.16.0
#
# Prerequisite: a running Kubernetes 1.32+ cluster with kubectl configured.
# KServe is installed via Helm when available, falling back to YAML.
set -e

KNATIVE_VERSION="v1.19.0"
ISTIO_VERSION="1.28.0"
CERT_MANAGER_VERSION="v1.15.0"
KSERVE_VERSION="v0.16.0"

# ── 1. Install Knative Serving ────────────────────────────────────────────────
echo "knative: installing Serving CRDs …"
kubectl apply -f "https://github.com/knative/serving/releases/download/knative-${KNATIVE_VERSION}/serving-crds.yaml"

echo "knative: installing Serving core …"
kubectl apply -f "https://github.com/knative/serving/releases/download/knative-${KNATIVE_VERSION}/serving-core.yaml"

echo "knative: waiting for Serving to be ready …"
kubectl wait --for=condition=Available deployment --all -n knative-serving --timeout=300s

# ── 2. Install Networking Layer (Istio + net-istio) ───────────────────────────
echo "istio  : downloading istioctl ${ISTIO_VERSION} …"
curl -sSL https://istio.io/downloadIstio | ISTIO_VERSION="${ISTIO_VERSION}" TARGET_ARCH="$(uname -m)" sh -
export PATH="${PWD}/istio-${ISTIO_VERSION}/bin:${PATH}"

echo "istio  : installing …"
istioctl install -y

echo "istio  : waiting for ingress gateway …"
kubectl wait --for=condition=Available deployment --all -n istio-system --timeout=300s

echo "istio  : installing Knative net-istio …"
kubectl apply -f "https://github.com/knative/net-istio/releases/download/knative-${KNATIVE_VERSION}/net-istio.yaml"

# ── 3. Install Cert Manager ───────────────────────────────────────────────────
echo "certmgr: installing Cert Manager ${CERT_MANAGER_VERSION} …"
kubectl apply -f "https://github.com/cert-manager/cert-manager/releases/download/${CERT_MANAGER_VERSION}/cert-manager.yaml"

echo "certmgr: waiting for Cert Manager to be ready …"
kubectl wait --for=condition=Available deployment --all -n cert-manager --timeout=300s

# ── 4. Install KServe ─────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
if command -v helm &>/dev/null; then
  echo "kserve : installing CRDs via Helm …"
  helm install kserve-crd oci://ghcr.io/kserve/charts/kserve-crd --version "${KSERVE_VERSION}"

  echo "kserve : installing controller via Helm …"
  helm install kserve oci://ghcr.io/kserve/charts/kserve --version "${KSERVE_VERSION}"
else
  echo "kserve : helm not found — installing via YAML …"
  kubectl apply --server-side \
    -f "https://github.com/kserve/kserve/releases/download/${KSERVE_VERSION}/kserve.yaml"

  echo "kserve : installing built-in ClusterServingRuntimes …"
  kubectl apply --server-side \
    -f "https://github.com/kserve/kserve/releases/download/${KSERVE_VERSION}/kserve-cluster-resources.yaml"
fi

echo "kserve : Knative mode installation complete"

lines: +  # The chart registers a ValidatingWebhookConfiguration and ClusterServingRuntimes
+  # in a single pass; the webhook pod may not be ready when CSRs are submitted,
+  # producing a "connection refused" error.  Allow that failure — the controller
+  # deployment is still created — and apply cluster resources once it is ready.
echo "kserve : helm not found — installing via YAML …"
+echo "kserve : waiting for controller manager to be ready …"

content.text:
What changed and why:

1. **`helm upgrade --install` instead of `helm install`** — makes the script idempotent on re-runs; `helm install` fails if a release already exists (even in FAILED state).

2. **`|| true` on the kserve chart install** — the controller deployment is still created by Helm even when the install is marked FAILED. The webhook timing error only affects the ClusterServingRuntimes step at the end of the transaction.

3. **Explicit `kubectl wait` for `kserve-controller-manager`** — blocks until the webhook server pod is actually serving before we touch any `ClusterServingRuntime` resources.

4. **`kserve-cluster-resources.yaml` applied after the wait** — this is the idempotent apply of all `ClusterServingRuntimes`. For the Helm path the webhook is now ready; for the YAML fallback path this replaces the inline apply that was inside the `else` block.
